At the same time one unlucky fraternity man from
each of the thirteen houses involved in rush this year
will march to Levering Hall to deliver the bid list for
his fraternity. This drama having played itself out,
as it does each year on Pledge Saturday, rush will be
over, and it will remain only for the various fraternities to pick up their hopeful charges and envelop
them in the protective arms of fraternalism.
Rush this year proceeded much as it has in the
past, with a handful of minor violations being handed
down by the I.F.C., but no major breaches of rush
regulations taking place. A note of interest was added
by the crackdown on beer carried out by the Baltimore City Police in conjunction with a massive revamping of the department. This caused the I.F.C. to
suspend the serving of beer for rush in an attempt
to preserve itself and the fraternity system.
A large percentage of the class of '69 is expected
to go fraternity. This, coupled with the facts that the
class is the largest in Hopkins history, and that Phi
Kappa Psi eliminated itself from rush by violating
the terms of its social probation promises growth for
most of the houses on campus. The tone, going into
Pledge Saturday, is optimistic, both among the freshmen and the fraternities.

By JOE WEINBERG
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of the UMversity, promised a full investigation of the food served
In the dormitory cafeteria in a special meeting at
Homewood House March 1. Dr. Eisenhower responded
to a 415 signature petition presented to him at the
meeting by three Hopkins freshmen. Plant manager of
the University Wesley Taylor, in whose department
the food service belongs, will conduct the investigation.
The petition, which was organized by freshmen Bob
Gayle, Richard Hammond, Bruce McLeish and Mark
Olman, asked for an investigation of the "inferior
quality of the food," because "the apparent lack of
.quality constitutes a serious detriment to our health
and morale." Included in the copies of the petition
presented to the administration were more specific
complaints such as the small size and quality of the
meat, the lack of proteins in the diet, the greasiness of
the meat, the shortage of garden vegetables and fresh
fruits, and the cleaning of the silver and glassware.
Dr. Eisenhower expressed a deep concern for the
situation in the cafeteria and promised action. Ham-.
mond, Olman, Gayle, and Taylor will meet next Tues.
day at 10:00 A.M. to further discuss the situation.
LaShaw Concerned
Mr. Howard LaShaw, director of the food service,
also expressed concern over the students' complaints.

REEXAMINED
The director stated that he would personally prepare
the menus for the dormitory and that "I'll be there
physically nine-tenths of the day. I will be right there
for all meals, observing the cooking." Mr. LaShaw
hoped to be able to talk to students during the meals
In order to hear specific complaints. "I'll very definitely
be up there from here on out," he repeated. "We do
want suggestions. The door is open every meal and
please stop by with any suggestions at all. We will be
more than glad to listen to them and put them into
effect. The fellows live here nine months out of the
year and we certainly want to try to keep thent
happy."
In addition to personally supervising the dormitory
cafeteria, LaShaw is surveying the menu's from the
past years to see if there really is lack of protein in the
planned diet. He also explained that the service only
buys top quality meats and other foods.
Gov't Stamped
All canned foods bear a certificate of quality and
condition from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
which checks that the cans meet the specifications.
The service only buys top grade, U.S. Choice- or U.S.
Good meat The government classifies meat as prime,
choice, good, and commercial in order of quality.
La Shaw emphasized that he was very interested in
specific complaints such as greasy food, and that
these would be acted upon promptly. He was puzzled
over what was different this year than other years
that the students should think that the food had become exceptionally bad. "The cooks are the same
people, the procedure the same, the meat quality is
the same."
Student Views
Student opinion in the dormitories seemed to agree
with the tone of the petition. Toby Simon, a senior,
stated that "the extremely bad quality of the dormitory food seems to be part of the general policy of
letting the dormitory facilities decay and becoming
less desirable to live in. Since I've been here the food
has gotten worse. Especially upsetting to me is the
unappetizing appearance of the food and the knowledge that the meat in particlar is of such low quality.

Guilty until proven innocent
The decision of the honor conmiission to make the
possession of master keys to Gilman, and other halls,
an honor violation over steps the logical jurisdiction
of the Honor Commission. Aside from the fact that the
decision makes the assumption that a person has taken
unfair advantage of his fellow students prior to any
fact of violation—the commission has extended its power
of judgement from within. As an unrepresentative body
the Honor Commission has no right to take such an
action, and while there is evidence that such action
should be taken—the matter should have been considered by the student council or sonic other representative
body. We support the student council in its protest of
the honor commission's decision.
The administration, as well, should have known
to approach the student council and not the honor
commission on this matter, but the decision of the
honor commission to accept the decision as their duly
is a violation of their responsibility to the student body.
We hope that in the future the honor commission will
act more wisely—besides their assumption that mere
possession of a key is an honor violation is tantamount
to admission that the honor system does not work—even
we do not believe that.

Good Works:
The Cost of Good Graces
In the eyes of the Baltimore public, fraternities
are as bad as their worst member. 11 is a typically
moronic view, but has made the fraternities appear, in
the last few weeks, to he harbors of vice.
Since this view can not be ignored, it should he appeased at every opportunity. Such an opportunity has
arisen, and we recommend very strongly that the fraternities let an image of their "hest member." have a tilt] exposure.
A group of students and faculty are attempting
to raise money for a scholarship drive for gifted underprivileged students. The drive has received the support
of Theatre Hopkins which is giving three benefit performances of "Boys from Syracuse," to mkt to the fund.
If the benefit performances are to make any substantial contribution, there must be a massive ticket
sale; and this is where the fraternities can help.
The plan is this: The fraternity will pledge to
purchase a certain number of tickets, 50 to 100 in
excess of what its members will need for themselves.
For the night of the performance, the fraternity invites
50 to 100 less-privileged or deprived children—ehildren
who might otherwise never have the chance to see a play
or even enter legitimately into a college community,
much less a fraternity house—to attend the performance as its guests at its expense.
By this plan, which will be administered through
the office of special events and Joluni Synodinos, the
fraternities provide an essential boost to the scholarship
drive; they give a young boy a glimpse of what the
inside of a theatre looks like; the fraternities show Baltimore their better half, by way of the prepared publicity to be done by John Synodinos; and the members
and their dates can enjoy themselves being mutually
gracious to an awed group of youngsters; A bargain
for such a great deal of beneficence.
The Committee of Special Events will administer
the details of the program. It will invite the children,
give extensive local and national publicity to the participating fraternities and handle the finances.
Though Fraternities would suffer no harm in trailing good works for good graces at this time, the project
need not be as mercenary as all that. The project has a
touching straightforwardness about it that is rare in
community action. It is a realizable reform with almost
guaranteed success, in the form of a simple kindness.

Bad Books
Nearly everyone is discontented with the bookstore.
The Hopkins Chapter of Students for a Democratic
Society acted favorably on a resolution for communalizing the bookstore. Though the floor expressed concern
that the issue was irrelevant to the resolution, or that
acting on such a trivial matter might enfeeble the local
chapter, the resolution passed with ease,
And the News-Leiter applauds them on this conBCH SUS. The News-Letter also points out that when the
majority of students complain about capitalistic oppression, when the long range planning committee supports their complaint, when even the post office is
heard to complain about their inefficiency and when
SDS is illing to compromise the resolution, something is bound to be wrong.

Last week the second annual
Student Art Exhibit opened in
the Eisenhower Library. The
show represents the combined
efforts of graduate students and
faculty members who have joined together to increase the level
of art consciousness on the Hopkins campus. The exhibit is
smaller than its previous predecessor but the quality is generally quite adequate with numerous works representing various
styles and approaches.

The works by Gabe Weisberg,
done in oil crayon, are spontaneous, possibly too much so. The
works captivate a viewer with
their strong color sequences suggesting moods of feeling are
quite intense, vibrating and
humorous. The most successful
of the three studies is the smallest, where the colors and forms
are well balanced. Perhaps all
the -works suffer because they
are too small, they seem to want
to burst the boundaries of their
small frames. The works could
have been more impressive if
they appeared as large abstract
oil paintings.
The two oil paintings by Sandra Hastings are also lively and
colorful. They lack an understanding of abstract structure
which makes them fall apart.
Her understanding of color is
quite adequate but her formal
arrangement in space is weak.
The large paintings by Dr.
George Owen represent a variety of styles from imitation Picasso, to amiable art nouveau,
to irridescent Pissarro. They
are, taken as a group, lacking
in originality although they are
lively and technically quite proficient. Dr. Owen has a good
grasp of the oil painting medium
which could be carried further,
with more time to devote to his
canvases.

Turnbull Lecture
BALTIMORE, Feb. 28—The
Turnbull Memorial Lectures, being given this year by poets and
scholars from Germany, Spain,
England, France and the United
States, will continue on March
8th with an address by Wolfgang Clemen, professor of English at the University of Munich.
Dr. Clemen's lecture on "The
Spirits in Shelley's Poetry" will
be given at 4 p.m. in the auditorium of the new classroom
building.
in Bonn, Professor
Born
Clemen was educated at the universities of Heidelberg, Freiburg,
Bonn and Cambridge. Before accepting his present post in 1946,
he taught at the University of
Cologne and the University of
Kiel.
From 1948 until 1962. he
served as Vice President of the
German Shakespeare Society
and co-editor of the Shakespeare
Jahrbuch. He is a member of
the Bavarian Academy of Sciences, a corresponding Fellow of
the British Academy and a member of the Committee for Cultural Affairs in the German
Foreign Office. In 1964 he was
.elected president of the Modern
Humanities Research Association.
Professor Clemen has published several works in English

the terms of its social probation promises growth for
most of the houses on campus. The tone, going into
Pledge Saturday, is optimistic, both among the freshmen and the fraternities.

By JOE WEINBERG
Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of the UMversity, promised a full investigation of the food served
In the dormitory cafeteria in a special meeting at
Homewood House March 1. Dr. Eisenhower responded
to a 415 signature petition presented to him at the
meeting by three Hopkins freshmen. Plant manager of
the University Wesley Taylor, in whose department
the food service belongs, will conduct the investigation.
The petition, which was organized by freshmen Bob
Gayle, Richard Hammond, Bruce McLeish and Mark
Olman, asked for an investigation of the "inferior
quality of the food," because "the apparent lack of
.quality constitutes a serious detriment to our health
and morale." Included in the copies of the petition
presented to the administration were more specific
complaints such as the small size and quality of the
meat, the lack of proteins in the diet, the greasiness of
the meat, the shortage of garden vegetables and fresh
fruits, and the cleaning of the silver and glassware.
Dr. Eisenhower expressed a deep concern for the
situation in the cafeteria and promised action. Ham-.
mond, Olman, Gayle, and Taylor will meet next Tues.
day at 10:00 A.M. to further discuss the situation.
LaShaw Concerned
Mr. Howard LaShaw, director of the food service,
also expressed concern over the students' complaints.

REEXAMINED
The director stated that he would personally prepare
the menus for the dormitory and that "I'll be there
physically nine-tenths of the day. I will be right there
for all meals, observing the cooking." Mr. LaShaw
hoped to be able to talk to students during the meals
In order to hear specific complaints. "I'll very definitely
be up there from here on out," he repeated. "We do
want suggestions. The door is open every meal and
please stop by with any suggestions at all. We will be
more than glad to listen to them and put them into
effect. The fellows live here nine months out of the
year and we certainly want to try to keep thent
happy."
In addition to personally supervising the dormitory
cafeteria, LaShaw is surveying the menu's from the
past years to see if there really is lack of protein in the
planned diet. He also explained that the service only
buys top quality meats and other foods.
Gov't Stamped
All canned foods bear a certificate of quality and
condition from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
which checks that the cans meet the specifications.
The service only buys top grade, U.S. Choice- or U.S.
Good meat The government classifies meat as prime,
choice, good, and commercial in order of quality.
La Shaw emphasized that he was very interested in
specific complaints such as greasy food, and that
these would be acted upon promptly. He was puzzled
over what was different this year than other years
that the students should think that the food had become exceptionally bad. "The cooks are the same
people, the procedure the same, the meat quality is
the same."
Student Views
Student opinion in the dormitories seemed to agree
with the tone of the petition. Toby Simon, a senior,
stated that "the extremely bad quality of the dormitory food seems to be part of the general policy of
letting the dormitory facilities decay and becoming
less desirable to live in. Since I've been here the food
has gotten worse. Especially upsetting to me is the
unappetizing appearance of the food and the knowledge that the meat in particlar is of such low quality.

Guilty until proven innocent
The decision of the honor conmiission to make the
possession of master keys to Gilman, and other halls,
an honor violation over steps the logical jurisdiction
of the Honor Commission. Aside from the fact that the
decision makes the assumption that a person has taken
unfair advantage of his fellow students prior to any
fact of violation—the commission has extended its power
of judgement from within. As an unrepresentative body
the Honor Commission has no right to take such an
action, and while there is evidence that such action
should be taken—the matter should have been considered by the student council or sonic other representative
body. We support the student council in its protest of
the honor commission's decision.
The administration, as well, should have known
to approach the student council and not the honor
commission on this matter, but the decision of the
honor commission to accept the decision as their duly
is a violation of their responsibility to the student body.
We hope that in the future the honor commission will
act more wisely—besides their assumption that mere
possession of a key is an honor violation is tantamount
to admission that the honor system does not work—even
we do not believe that.

A group of students and faculty are attempting
to raise money for a scholarship drive for gifted underprivileged students. The drive has received the support
of Theatre Hopkins which is giving three benefit performances of "Boys from Syracuse," to mkt to the fund.
If the benefit performances are to make any substantial contribution, there must be a massive ticket
sale; and this is where the fraternities can help.
The plan is this: The fraternity will pledge to
purchase a certain number of tickets, 50 to 100 in
excess of what its members will need for themselves.
For the night of the performance, the fraternity invites
50 to 100 less-privileged or deprived children—ehildren
who might otherwise never have the chance to see a play
or even enter legitimately into a college community,
much less a fraternity house—to attend the performance as its guests at its expense.
By this plan, which will be administered through
the office of special events and Joluni Synodinos, the
fraternities provide an essential boost to the scholarship
drive; they give a young boy a glimpse of what the
inside of a theatre looks like; the fraternities show Baltimore their better half, by way of the prepared publicity to be done by John Synodinos; and the members
and their dates can enjoy themselves being mutually
gracious to an awed group of youngsters; A bargain
for such a great deal of beneficence.
The Committee of Special Events will administer
the details of the program. It will invite the children,
give extensive local and national publicity to the participating fraternities and handle the finances.
Though Fraternities would suffer no harm in trailing good works for good graces at this time, the project
need not be as mercenary as all that. The project has a
touching straightforwardness about it that is rare in
community action. It is a realizable reform with almost
guaranteed success, in the form of a simple kindness.

Bad Books
Nearly everyone is discontented with the bookstore.
The Hopkins Chapter of Students for a Democratic
Society acted favorably on a resolution for communalizing the bookstore. Though the floor expressed concern
that the issue was irrelevant to the resolution, or that
acting on such a trivial matter might enfeeble the local
chapter, the resolution passed with ease,
And the News-Leiter applauds them on this conBCH SUS. The News-Letter also points out that when the
majority of students complain about capitalistic oppression, when the long range planning committee supports their complaint, when even the post office is
heard to complain about their inefficiency and when
SDS is illing to compromise the resolution, something is bound to be wrong.

Last week the second annual
Student Art Exhibit opened in
the Eisenhower Library. The
show represents the combined
efforts of graduate students and
faculty members who have joined together to increase the level
of art consciousness on the Hopkins campus. The exhibit is
smaller than its previous predecessor but the quality is generally quite adequate with numerous works representing various
styles and approaches.

The works by Gabe Weisberg,
done in oil crayon, are spontaneous, possibly too much so. The
works captivate a viewer with
their strong color sequences suggesting moods of feeling are
quite intense, vibrating and
humorous. The most successful
of the three studies is the smallest, where the colors and forms
are well balanced. Perhaps all
the -works suffer because they
are too small, they seem to want
to burst the boundaries of their
small frames. The works could
have been more impressive if
they appeared as large abstract
oil paintings.
The two oil paintings by Sandra Hastings are also lively and
colorful. They lack an understanding of abstract structure
which makes them fall apart.
Her understanding of color is
quite adequate but her formal
arrangement in space is weak.
The large paintings by Dr.
George Owen represent a variety of styles from imitation Picasso, to amiable art nouveau,
to irridescent Pissarro. They
are, taken as a group, lacking
in originality although they are
lively and technically quite proficient. Dr. Owen has a good
grasp of the oil painting medium
which could be carried further,
with more time to devote to his
canvases.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 28—The

States, will continue on March

Spirits in Shelley's Poetry" will
be given at 4 p.m. in the auditorium of the new classroom
building.
in Bonn, Professor
Born
Clemen was educated at the universities of Heidelberg, Freiburg,
Bonn and Cambridge. Before accepting his present post in 1946,
he taught at the University of
Cologne and the University of
Kiel.
From 1948 until 1962. he
served as Vice President of the
German Shakespeare Society
and co-editor of the Shakespeare
Jahrbuch. He is a member of
the Bavarian Academy of Sciences, a corresponding Fellow of
the British Academy and a member of the Committee for Cultural Affairs in the German
Foreign Office. In 1964 he was
.elected president of the Modern
Humanities Research Association.

Today's article focuses on the
attack.
Problem number one for the
varsity lacrosse team is that it
lacks a ready-made offense for
the first time in years.
Coach Bob Scott goes into
this week carrying sixteen sophomores, an untried attack. a
basically good midfield that lacks
depth, a top-notch defense, and
a big question mark in the goal.
